comment: Moscow Variation -- After this White will either establish a white square pawn formation (Pc4, Pe4) to replace the effect of the bishop (to the extent they can) or aim for c2-c3, d2-d4 and possibly d4-d5 or e4-e5. The move also works to enable O-O quickly. 3. Bc4 is interesting and has been played recently, but 3. d4 is still the most common move.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6
comment: This is unusual, but not necessarily bad. If White captures Nc6 Black can recapture ...b7xc6 and have better central control. Perhaps Polgar is trying to take Kasparov out of familiar territory.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5
comment: This makes Bf8 bad and doesn't prevent White from playing c2-c3, d2-d4 to open the center.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3
comment: Already Black faces a crisis since White is better developed and Ke8 might soon be exposed.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5
comment: This could be the move of a complete amateur or of a great player such as Ivanchuk, but it seems out of place and unusual, for Polgar. This may be a small indication of an internal struggle wherein she tries to expand her approach, hopefully for the better. In this case I think it just fails.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4
comment: Opening the center is more important than the pawn he appears to be gambitting.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4
comment: practically begging for ...d6-d5, so he can open the e-file with exd5

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1
comment: quite likely planning 12. e5 d5 13. Nd6+

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7
comment: Developing this piece to this square is usually normal, but in this case it's very strange. It helps keep the e-file blocked, but how are the king-side pieces to be developed and used? I'm not certain what Black's plan might be.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8
comment: This position doesn't look too good for Black, but Na3 is misplaced and Nd6 is far from coordinating with other White pieces.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8 15. Bf4
comment: Kasparov just holds onto Nd6 and keeps an eye on how Black is going to proceed, looking for ways to gain advantage.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8 15. Bf4 h5 16. b4 c4 17. Qxd4
comment: Pd5 is in danger of being captured by Na3-b5-c3xd5 and I don't see a very good defense for Black.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8 15. Bf4 h5 16. b4 c4 17. Qxd4 h4 18. Nab5 Rh5
comment: White takes over the center while Black squirms out of the corner. Is this sufficient to prevent White from crashing through the center? Well, first of all Pa7 is en prise, so White has to decide whether there is time to capture it and then return to the main theme.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8 15. Bf4 h5 16. b4 c4 17. Qxd4 h4 18. Nab5 Rh5 19. Qe3 Qd7
comment: Finally Black's position seems to hold together.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8 15. Bf4 h5 16. b4 c4 17. Qxd4 h4 18. Nab5 Rh5 19. Qe3 Qd7 20. Nd4 Bd8
comment: perhaps considering ...Bd8-b6, but also clearing e7 to develop Ng8-e7-g6

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8 15. Bf4 h5 16. b4 c4 17. Qxd4 h4 18. Nab5 Rh5 19. Qe3 Qd7 20. Nd4 Bd8 21. Qd2 Ne7
comment: This position requires a comment. It appears Black has secured her king, but there's more of interest here. Black's advanced king-side pawns might give her a chance for some offense while it's not really clear White has any offense at all. The only factor which makes the position really murky is the blocked center. White has more space and Qd7 is dreadful, but can White actually penetrate Black's position? White can advance his queen-side pawns, but the king-side seems to be in Black's hands! This is an amazing realization to make after that peculiar opening. Perhaps a classicist would simply indicate that the immediate position doesn't appear winning for White, but Black will be compelled to make more moves and in so doing will unravel. We'll see.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8 15. Bf4 h5 16. b4 c4 17. Qxd4 h4 18. Nab5 Rh5 19. Qe3 Qd7 20. Nd4 Bd8 21. Qd2 Ne7 22. b5 Ng6 23. Nc6 c3
comment: chasing White's queen away from control of d4, so ...Bb6 can't be met by Nc6-d4

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8 15. Bf4 h5 16. b4 c4 17. Qxd4 h4 18. Nab5 Rh5 19. Qe3 Qd7 20. Nd4 Bd8 21. Qd2 Ne7 22. b5 Ng6 23. Nc6 c3 24. Qc1 g3
comment: And, this is clearly too far-fetched.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8 15. Bf4 h5 16. b4 c4 17. Qxd4 h4 18. Nab5 Rh5 19. Qe3 Qd7 20. Nd4 Bd8 21. Qd2 Ne7 22. b5 Ng6 23. Nc6 c3 24. Qc1 g3 25. fxg3 hxg3 26. Bxg3 Bb6+ 27. Kh1
comment: Though Polgar has a rook on the h-file he would rather crouch behind the pawns than be flushed out to f1, or worse e2.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8 15. Bf4 h5 16. b4 c4 17. Qxd4 h4 18. Nab5 Rh5 19. Qe3 Qd7 20. Nd4 Bd8 21. Qd2 Ne7 22. b5 Ng6 23. Nc6 c3 24. Qc1 g3 25. fxg3 hxg3 26. Bxg3 Bb6+ 27. Kh1 Kg7 28. Qxc3 Rah8 29. Rf1 Kg8 30. Rae1 f5
comment: She wants to bring Qd7 to the h-file and/or to use ...f5-f4 to chase away Bg3, but king safety is the first priority! Allowing exf6 is extremely risky. If only there was another way, but I see none. I suppose this is where the classicist says, "I told you so." Black is having difficult with Qd7 because White dominates in the center, cramping Black quite a lot. So, when Black fights back those central pieces spring into action!

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8 15. Bf4 h5 16. b4 c4 17. Qxd4 h4 18. Nab5 Rh5 19. Qe3 Qd7 20. Nd4 Bd8 21. Qd2 Ne7 22. b5 Ng6 23. Nc6 c3 24. Qc1 g3 25. fxg3 hxg3 26. Bxg3 Bb6+ 27. Kh1 Kg7 28. Qxc3 Rah8 29. Rf1 Kg8 30. Rae1 f5 31. exf6 Qh7
comment: threatening ...Rxh2+ mating

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8 15. Bf4 h5 16. b4 c4 17. Qxd4 h4 18. Nab5 Rh5 19. Qe3 Qd7 20. Nd4 Bd8 21. Qd2 Ne7 22. b5 Ng6 23. Nc6 c3 24. Qc1 g3 25. fxg3 hxg3 26. Bxg3 Bb6+ 27. Kh1 Kg7 28. Qxc3 Rah8 29. Rf1 Kg8 30. Rae1 f5 31. exf6 Qh7 32. f7+ Bxf7 33. Qxh8+
comment: forced, to avoid the checkmate

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8 15. Bf4 h5 16. b4 c4 17. Qxd4 h4 18. Nab5 Rh5 19. Qe3 Qd7 20. Nd4 Bd8 21. Qd2 Ne7 22. b5 Ng6 23. Nc6 c3 24. Qc1 g3 25. fxg3 hxg3 26. Bxg3 Bb6+ 27. Kh1 Kg7 28. Qxc3 Rah8 29. Rf1 Kg8 30. Rae1 f5 31. exf6 Qh7 32. f7+ Bxf7 33. Qxh8+ Nxh8
comment: After this the position is changed dramatically and Black's king is in as much, or more, danger than White's.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8 15. Bf4 h5 16. b4 c4 17. Qxd4 h4 18. Nab5 Rh5 19. Qe3 Qd7 20. Nd4 Bd8 21. Qd2 Ne7 22. b5 Ng6 23. Nc6 c3 24. Qc1 g3 25. fxg3 hxg3 26. Bxg3 Bb6+ 27. Kh1 Kg7 28. Qxc3 Rah8 29. Rf1 Kg8 30. Rae1 f5 31. exf6 Qh7 32. f7+ Bxf7 33. Qxh8+ Nxh8 34. Ne7+ Kf8 35. Nec8
comment: This is a marvelous situation: Bf7 is pinned, Nh8 is stuck defending Bf7 and Qh7 & Rh5 can only sit on the h-file, but they can't open it. White has completely foiled Black's plan, but at a cost. The only question is whether White can finally get to the very exposed Kf8 because a failure to do so would probably allow Black to consolidate and win with her queen.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8 15. Bf4 h5 16. b4 c4 17. Qxd4 h4 18. Nab5 Rh5 19. Qe3 Qd7 20. Nd4 Bd8 21. Qd2 Ne7 22. b5 Ng6 23. Nc6 c3 24. Qc1 g3 25. fxg3 hxg3 26. Bxg3 Bb6+ 27. Kh1 Kg7 28. Qxc3 Rah8 29. Rf1 Kg8 30. Rae1 f5 31. exf6 Qh7 32. f7+ Bxf7 33. Qxh8+ Nxh8 34. Ne7+ Kf8 35. Nec8 Qd3
comment: This looks like a time pressure move. It's quite ineffective. The threat is ...Qxg3.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8 15. Bf4 h5 16. b4 c4 17. Qxd4 h4 18. Nab5 Rh5 19. Qe3 Qd7 20. Nd4 Bd8 21. Qd2 Ne7 22. b5 Ng6 23. Nc6 c3 24. Qc1 g3 25. fxg3 hxg3 26. Bxg3 Bb6+ 27. Kh1 Kg7 28. Qxc3 Rah8 29. Rf1 Kg8 30. Rae1 f5 31. exf6 Qh7 32. f7+ Bxf7 33. Qxh8+ Nxh8 34. Ne7+ Kf8 35. Nec8 Qd3 36. Rf3 Qc2 37. Nxf7 Nxf7 38. Nd6 Qg6 39. Rxf7+ Qxf7 40. Nxf7 Kxf7
comment: After all that it seems terribly unfair that her heroic efforts to get active pieces was all dissipated, only to produce a losing ending.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8 15. Bf4 h5 16. b4 c4 17. Qxd4 h4 18. Nab5 Rh5 19. Qe3 Qd7 20. Nd4 Bd8 21. Qd2 Ne7 22. b5 Ng6 23. Nc6 c3 24. Qc1 g3 25. fxg3 hxg3 26. Bxg3 Bb6+ 27. Kh1 Kg7 28. Qxc3 Rah8 29. Rf1 Kg8 30. Rae1 f5 31. exf6 Qh7 32. f7+ Bxf7 33. Qxh8+ Nxh8 34. Ne7+ Kf8 35. Nec8 Qd3 36. Rf3 Qc2 37. Nxf7 Nxf7 38. Nd6 Qg6 39. Rxf7+ Qxf7 40. Nxf7 Kxf7 41. Re5
comment: Getting rid of the rooks makes good sense, as it makes the advance of Pg2 & Ph2 much easier.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Nc6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O e5 6. c3 g5 7. d4 g4 8. Nfd2 cxd4 9. cxd4 exd4 10. Nc4 c5 11. Re1 Be6 12. Nba3 Be7 13. e5 d5 14. Nd6+ Kf8 15. Bf4 h5 16. b4 c4 17. Qxd4 h4 18. Nab5 Rh5 19. Qe3 Qd7 20. Nd4 Bd8 21. Qd2 Ne7 22. b5 Ng6 23. Nc6 c3 24. Qc1 g3 25. fxg3 hxg3 26. Bxg3 Bb6+ 27. Kh1 Kg7 28. Qxc3 Rah8 29. Rf1 Kg8 30. Rae1 f5 31. exf6 Qh7 32. f7+ Bxf7 33. Qxh8+ Nxh8 34. Ne7+ Kf8 35. Nec8 Qd3 36. Rf3 Qc2 37. Nxf7 Nxf7 38. Nd6 Qg6 39. Rxf7+ Qxf7 40. Nxf7 Kxf7 41. Re5 Rxe5 42. Bxe5 d4 43. Kg1 Ke6 44. Bb8 Kd5 45. Kf1 Kc4 46. Ke2 d3+ 47. Kd1 Kxb5 48. h4 a5 49. Be5 Bf2 50. h5 Be3 51. Bg7
comment: Black loses her bishop after h5-h6 and Pg2 will keep Black occupied defensively while White's king gobbles Pd3 & Pa5 to clear the way for Pa2 to advance. This was quite an exciting game with the odd appearances and Polgar's heroic effort to gain piece activity, only to have it fall apart as they neared the time control (assuming that was move 40) .
